## How to Create a Make-shift Sun Compass for Navigation

### Table of Contents
- [Introduction](#introduction)
- [Materials/Tools](#materials-tools)
- [Step-by-Step Procedure](#step-by-step-procedure)
- [Tips and Considerations](#tips-and-considerations)
- [Troubleshooting](#troubleshooting)
- [Safety Measures](#safety-measures)
- [Common Mistakes to Avoid](#common-mistakes-to-avoid)
- [Summary and Key Takeaways](#summary-and-key-takeaways)

### Introduction
A make-shift sun compass can be a valuable tool for navigation when you find yourself without a traditional compass. By using the sun's position in the sky, you can determine your approximate direction. This guide will walk you through the steps to create a simple sun compass using basic materials.

### Materials/Tools
- A stick or rod
- A flat surface (e.g., the ground or a table)
- A watch or clock with a minute hand
- A clear and sunny day

### Step-by-Step Procedure
1. Find a clear and sunny location where you can easily see the sun's position in the sky.
2. Place the stick or rod vertically into the ground or onto a flat surface.
3. Use the watch or clock to determine the current time. Ensure that the watch or clock has a minute hand.
4. Align the stick or rod so that it casts a shadow on the ground.
5. Mark the tip of the shadow with a small object or by drawing a line.
6. Wait for approximately 10-15 minutes.
7. Observe the movement of the shadow and mark the new tip.
8. Draw a straight line connecting the two marks.
9. Stand with the first mark on your left and the second mark on your right.
10. The line between the marks represents an approximate east-west direction.
11. To determine north, stand with the first mark on your left and face the line between the marks. North will be in the direction opposite to the line.

### Tips and Considerations
- Choose a location with an unobstructed view of the sky to accurately observe the sun's position.
- Ensure that the stick or rod is straight and firmly planted to prevent it from moving.
- Repeat the process at different times of the day for more accurate results.
- Remember that the sun's position changes throughout the year, so adjust your compass accordingly.

### Troubleshooting
- If the shadow is not clear or distinct, try adjusting the angle of the stick or rod to create a sharper shadow.
- In case of cloudy weather, this method may not work as the sun's position may not be visible.

### Safety Measures
- Be cautious when handling the stick or rod to avoid injury.
- Protect your eyes from direct exposure to the sun by wearing sunglasses or a hat.

### Common Mistakes to Avoid
- Failing to wait for the shadow to move before marking the second point can result in an inaccurate compass.
- Neglecting to account for the sun's position changing throughout the day can lead to incorrect directions.

### Summary and Key Takeaways
Creating a make-shift sun compass can be a useful skill when traditional compasses are unavailable. By following the steps outlined in this guide, you can determine approximate directions using the sun's position in the sky. Remember to choose a clear and sunny location, mark the shadow's movement, and align yourself correctly to get accurate results.
